awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Return Migrants, Violent Electoral Politics and Electoral Integrity
awd_abstract_narration:
Electoral violence before, during, and after elections is common in middle-income democracies that produce large numbers of international migrants who retain social, political, and economic ties with those countries from abroad.  This project addresses whether return migrants can strengthen electoral integrity and competition in countries at risk of electoral violence by examining candidates who run for mayor in Mexico after living as immigrants in the United States. Mexican mayoral candidates and their family members face significant risks of being murdered or violently attacked; yet, as many as 30 percent of elected mayors previously lived in the US. The project examines whether return-migrant candidates have access to resources and capacities that enhance resilience against violence and the ability to accommodate violent actors, advancing knowledge relevant to policies on migration management and the reduction of electoral violence's negative repercussions on democratic competition and electoral integrity. 

To examine return migrants in the context of violent elections, this project surveys a national sample of approximately 1,100 mayoral candidates during the two months leading up to Mexico's 2021 election. Respondents are drawn from a list of 2,100 candidates developed using a stratified sampling design that involves a random selection from each Mexican state's official candidate registry with an oversampling from municipalities with higher migration. Survey questions address personal migration experiences and access to migration-driven resources and capacities, including cross-border networks, migration-generated wealth, experiences with crime and criminal justice in the United States, and facilities for crossing the US-Mexico border. Candidates are also asked about other factors that influence candidates' choices to run for office, such as political socialization within Mexico, party affiliation, personal attributes, and socio-economic status. The survey data are merged with publicly available municipal-level data for analysis.  As the first large-n survey in the world that examines candidates' migration experiences extensively, the project provides methodological lessons for future surveys in other countries affected by migration to the US and electoral violence, including El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Guatemala.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Local elections in Mexico are marred by violence. In 2012, 51 candidates for local offices withdrew before election day under threat from violent criminal organizations. The 2018 electoral season witnessed the murder of more than 48 mayoral candidates and at least 627 incidents of non-lethal violence against local leaders or party activists. Leading up to the June 2021 elections, 102 political leaders or activists were killed, including 36 mayoral candidates, and there occurred an additional 964 incidents of violence against political leaders and party activists. The fact that running for mayor is such a dangerous endeavor begs the question of who chooses to run under these conditions and how they mitigate the associated risks. 

Studies carried out within a few Mexican states suggest that 18 to 30 percent of Mexican mayors lived in the United States as immigrants prior to running for office in their communities of origin. Research on returning migrants who run for office shows that migration experiences can strengthen prospective candidates? political efficacy and capabilities and provide resources, including wealth, knowledge, and transnational networks that enhance candidates? electoral prospects. Building on this research, this project aimed to examine whether migration experiences enable candidates to manage the risks associated with running for local office in Mexico's violent settings. It aimed to survey approximately 800 mayors running for office in the June 2021 elections and to compare the responses of those with and without migration experiences and migration-derived resources and networks. 

The research produced two datasets from two rounds of telephone surveys. The first, which includes responses from 114 mayoral candidates and elected mayors, occurred between April 28 and October 31, 2021; the second, which includes responses from 32 candidates and elected mayors, occurred between November of 2021 and August of 2022.  Respondents hail from 21 of Mexico's 31 states, plus Mexico City. 

A significant proportion of Mexico?s mayoral candidates have US migration experiences. Of the candidates in the sample, 22 percent had lived in the United States for at least nine months. About 19 percent held a passport from a country other than Mexico, nearly three percent held US residency, and 24 percent held a US nonimmigrant visa. Eight percent of all candidates reported that they lacked legal authorization to live, work, or study in the US during their last stay there. Over four percent had been arrested in the US and five percent had been deported. 

Candidates' ties with emigrants living abroad were more extensive than among the general Mexican population. Nearly 15 percent received remittances a few times a year or more. About  23% communicated with people living in the US several times per week or more. Nearly 16% had engaged or planned to engage in campaign activities in the US.

Migration experiences may affect candidates? propensity to participate in politics and perhaps run for office. Of those who had lived abroad for over nine months, nearly 82 percent strongly agreed with the statement ?I participate more in public affairs now than before, after having lived, worked, or studied in the US? 

Cross-border economic activities may strengthen individuals? capacity to run in Mexico?s violent contexts. 13 percent of candidates own a transnational business (moving company, international shipping, import-export, or migration facilitation). 20 percent had produced public goods within Mexico in collaboration with emigrants living in the US using migrant remittances and, of those, 43% had prior migration experiences. 

Experiences with violence were no different for candidates who had lived in the US or received remittances. However, candidates who owned transnational businesses and those who communicated with migrants living in the US were more likely to report that they or their family members had been victims of violence or received threats of violence. 

The resulting sample size is insufficient to carry out the proposed analysis. Established methods for recruiting a large sample of elite survey participants were ineffective because Mexican mayoral candidates are neither elites nor state officials, but rather locally influential individuals who are not integrated with other elites within their state, much less with national elites. There are no national or subnational directories of candidates. State election institutes govern elections, including the publication of candidate lists, yet state-level political parties (as many as 10 for each federal entity) hold candidates? contact information private. Since most mayoral candidates are not incumbents, they are not subject to transparency laws and party organizations rebuffed PI?s written requests for contact information. Time between the publication of candidate lists and election day, averaged five weeks, limiting PI?s time to obtain contact information, recruit, and interview participants. PI obtained information for over 1200 candidates through a resource-intensive process that involved scouring webpages and communicating with directly with campaign staff, but most candidates were unwilling to participate, indicating that they were too busy campaigning. 

Datasets are published on the Harvard Dataverse.
